public sector customers is really two trends and two reasons for why they are increasingly looking to cloud one is to
drive innovation right and oftentimes it's truly disruptive innovation right so putting functionality and capability
at their fingertips to allow government agencies and their solutions providers to do more in the cloud right we also
see is a lot of public sector customers truly do appreciate the agility that they get via the AWS cloud we had a
panel in our second session today we had some stakeholders from the Department of Justice and US Marshal Service that
talked about having that agility and that flexibility to right-size their infrastructure by compute capacity and
not have to worry about waiting a year to get infrastructure just to find out it was the wrong set of infrastructure
to address the wrong sets and requirements right so that flexibility to make changes to fail fast to succeed
fast and to keep iterating to address their constituents and the capabilities they want to
to serve their mission we also see public sector customers turning to cloud to build new skill sets for their
employees their developers their administrators etc and oftentimes when you look across the innovation and the
agility and the new skill sets most customers are also unlocking significant cost savings by moving to the cloud we
also see government organizations and government agencies turning the cloud to truly deliver game changing the world
changing capabilities both in the US and abroad right so whether it's economic development or improving education and
research right improving citizen services and delivering value to their constituents it's really the combination
of game-changing projects and capabilities and innovation in the public sector space that's driving them
to look at clout during that session honest I also talked about the
requirements that truly do shape the public sectors adoption of cloud and we
all know that while the capabilities are there for them to do more oftentimes
their requirements security policies mandates and directives that will
influence how much a public sector organization can adopt cloud right
whether it's at the federal level where you have security policies laws and regulations and compliance regimes at

IT but cloud in general we see the same thing for state and local governments right oftentimes they'll point to the
federal government as a standard but nonetheless they still have laws and regulations and compliance requirements
that they have to meet in the cloud as well and it's fundamentally for those
reasons that we built AWS gov solve us right we launched the region in August of 2011 specifically
with the focus on public sector organizations and solutions providers and private sector companies and
regulated industries that had a higher bar to meet in terms of security and compliance right so either very
stringent regulations very stringent compliance requirements or quite frankly just sensitive data and regulated

and four CJIs if you're dealing with sensitive law enforcement and public safety data IRS 1075 to dealing with

the option to use service endpoints that are fits 140 - to validated and from
there NIST 853 and 800 171 if you're dealing with sensitive government data
to include systems and applications hosted in non-government facilities and

what's required to actually deliver that we really see a couple different segments here right there are contract

there are core set of AWS services that oftentimes those software products are

us will give not just customers right but software vendors an avenue to offer

hi for many of you this might be some repeat information but I actually want

we've commonly heard and it's consistent among enterprise customers as well as

depending on where they are on their journey to the cloud whether they're just starting off moving some basic web
application workloads over or they've decided to go all-in on the cloud and shut down their data center footprint
and migrate hundreds or thousands of application workloads over the software
the mix of the vendors that they deal with and how they're going to manage those vendors and procure the software
and pay for that software is all going to change and the reason that it's changing is because the nature of the
workload that's running in cloud can be dynamic and change day to day can change
our our it may change month to month compared to the way that it operated on Prem or as a more fragile environment
where they couldn't touch things in real time I am definitely having some clicker
issues okay
I'm not going to read through each of these bullets but if you think about the
software portfolio and how it's switching what we're largely hearing from most enterprise customers and large
government entities boils down to the fourth the fourth bullet on that slide
which is that they're going to shrink the portfolio of software application vendors that they have under contract
and management and look to leverage a smaller set of vendors that are more agile and innovative that are running on
the cloud that is a consistent piece of feedback we've heard probably now for about the past 18 months and then what
we also hear from customers are the challenge that they have and I'll tell you that the number one challenge we hear from customers is around
procurement of the software that it takes too long they're not able to
deploy it in a model that matches their workload needs on cloud even in some cases that the EULA that they're signing
up for that they deployed on-premise not match the use case that they're running when they migrate to AWS and so we've
largely set out to fix those issues with the marketplace where the catalog that enables customers to deploy both byl
solution so that our licenses that they already own and can migrate over to AWS and deploy with no additional cost for
the software and run on top of AWS infrastructure like ec2 or secure a net
new solution for a workload that they're either migrating over or deciding to build on
and we do that through a mechanism where we set up a digital catalog of software
that we curate and manage and we launched that in April of 2012 so we're
past our five-year anniversary and we're now over 3,800 software application
listings from eleven hundred and seventy is DS that sell their product to customers that have an AWS account out
of this digital catalog and in doing so we now clock more than 135 thousand
active customers that utilize the AWS marketplace each month to buy and deploy
their software and it generates more than three hundred and seventy million hours of deployed ECT to software each
month as a result of customers deploying those Amazon machine images in addition
to that in April of this year at San Francisco summit we launched something called SAS contracts and the reason we
did that was we wanted customers and SAS companies that were running on AWS to
have the capability of buying SAS subscriptions two popular SAS software
products from companies like Splunk or box or app dynamics and be able to buy
into in terms of one two and three year contracts and receive a discount for
that we innovated around that by enabling a customer to start off using a
SAS product without having to make a long-term commitment and at any point
automatically hit a button to upgrade to a one two or three-year subscription so you can be running monthly and upgrade
to annual you can be running annual and upgrade to two-year and so on and it automatically gets instantly added to
the customers AWS bill and it absolutely reduces the friction that customers now
have of procuring software from the software vendor however we got a lot of
feedback from our ISPs that they said look we still want to be able to support
our customers we still want to be able to be in contact with our customers we want to know who our customers are that
are buying software in the same went for consulting and channel partners that we're representing those eyes
helping make recommendations or buying on behalf of a customer as a value-added reseller and so we added a feature
earlier this year to called product support connection and it enables the customer to enter all of their
information upon checkout their name phone number email address project
they're working on company etc and it allows our ifvs or a VAR selling on
behalf of an ISV to come into the marketplace via API and pull that information into their customer support
and CRM system so that when the customer calls for help the is V or VAR knows
exactly who the customer is and that's a feature that both our sellers channel partners and customers ask for and I'd
be remiss if I didn't mention that this is not a wild wild west of software we
do operate this as a publicly managed and curated catalog and to run through this slide quickly to simply say that
every product that goes into the catalog whether it's open source from a firm
like sent OS whether to security or networking product from companies like Cisco or f5 or juniper or Splunk or any
other solution that might go into the marketplace have to pass the same security bar and test that is prescribed
by AWS in addition we don't allow alpha or beta software into the catalog and
for any type of startup my team does do a business validation with that company to make sure that they do have
referenceable customers and they have some type of support process in place for the customer
now once the product is in the catalog we monitor that product for any vulnerability or security risk on a 24
by 7 basis and if we discover one we both notify the ISP to fix it and customers who are running that product
so that they can do any Patchen that might be available in their environment and then just a snapshot of a bit of the
categories and vendors there are 23 categories represented in the marketplace today but
a few of them are heavily used by customers when they begin or are
actively moving all in on the cloud particularly in the operating system security and networking space and then
customers begin to look at data sets that need to move over and what third-party storage software they might need to help integrate with s3 or to
move data into redshift from solutions like matil yin even devops types of
tools for the customers that are looking for retail locations or looking at any
type of demographic data they may use a GIS solution from one of the vendors that's listed here and then once that
data is in we offer a wide variety of BI tools to do analysis and this is by no
means a representation of all all eleven hundred and seventy is fees that are
selling but it does give you an idea that there are both small and big as well as open source products that are
available in the catalog okay and as we
mentioned we announced that today in late summer we will be adding gov cloud capability on to the marketplace so that
it's a region that customers can choose when they find a solution that can be able to pick gov cloud as a region that
they can deploy a solution to and over time we'll move all of the features and
capabilities that are available in the commercial marketplace today we will layer those into functionality for that
region as well just as a just as we do with other regions that come online nothing will change in terms of how we
mechanize what customers can do though we'll still put the software on to the AWS bill on behalf of the customer will
still collect the fees from the customer will still disperse disburse funds to
the ISP seller in the marketplace for the solution that the customers purchased so none of the actual
operational cadence the way that we operate the marketplace will change is simply another region for customers that
need to run that software inside of gov cloud and then lastly I did want to talk
about additional innovations and we got a bunch of questions on these actually on Monday in terms of well we know
customers want to buy software potentially by the hour particularly for workloads that spin-up
or spin-down rather quickly you know nobody wants to run software 24 by 7 nobody wants to buy
licenses that stretch out for a year if the workload is only going to spin up and spin down for a total of a few days
in accumulative hours but one of the features that we launched last year in a
program that my team runs is called private pricing and it enables a customer and ISV or their representative
channel partner to negotiate a custom price for a piece of software over a
duration launch that product privately out of marketplace behind the scenes and
then the marketplace team takes that SKU and the negotiated price and loads it
into the customers bill so as an example if I have an ISV that's going to
negotiate on a three-year subscription for a piece of software and let's say
the customer wants to pay X amount of dollars for that software over a three-year period of time we can take
that transaction between the ISV or the representative channel partner and the customer we can load that three-year
subscription in the agreement to pay over three years into the system on the anniversary date of the due date over
the course of the three years we build a customer collect the revenue from the customer distribute the appropriate
funds to the is V and we enable that product to be deployed out of the
marketplace behind the scene so that nobody else sees that price with the customer and the vendor or channel
partner that's negotiated it and it's a pretty straightforward process that our team runs today and it will be available
to gulf cloud customers as soon as we are up later this summer we also will
offer hybrid metered pricing this one is super important and the reason this is important is that most customers are
running some type of hybrid workload environment today they may be running a VMware stack on-prem in their own data
center and migrating a set of workload assets over to AWS as they do that they
often want to use the same type the software between both environments but they want the flexibility of the
pricing model that is offered in the marketplace which many ISPs could not
offer on Prem for example metering the number of nodes that are protected during a given month and being able to
accurately count the number of nodes that are protected as the workload expands and contracts throughout the
month and over a given period of time we do have available in the commercial marketplace today the ability for a
customer to deploy out a marketplace with metered pricing if a vendor attaches to that feature we've launched
and build a customer for all the software that they have running for those nodes protected on Prem or
anywhere else that those nodes happen to be running as well as the nodes that
they have running on AWS for the workloads that they've migrated we pull
all that pricing into a single bill at the end of each month when we put that on the customers AWS bill and the feedback we've gotten from CIOs is
awesome now I can see my entire fleet of nodes that I need to protect choose a
single vendor and pricing plan for the solution and have it all in a central dashboard called my software inside of
AWS where I can manage both what I'm being charged as well as when I'm protected and then lastly I talked a bit
about SAS SAS subscriptions on SAS contracts again enables a customer to subscribe to you a SAS product we define
a SAS product as software running inside of the software vendors account on AWS
so if I take out Dynamics as an example if a customer goes and subscribes to app dynamics that software is running inside
of the app dynamics AWS account I'm simply subscribing to a pricing plan based on what my needs are one two or
